-RUSHING PRIVATE RYAN-

We set out in the morning, warily checking windows, corners, anywhere the Germans could spring a trap or an ambush.

Johannson was in the lead, Garand at the ready and bayonet fixed improperly.  Rook was shadowing him, double checking each spot that Johannson had checked before.  I was in the middle with Peters, helping him carry the M2 Browning.  And Stewart was in the rear, covering our backs with his Thompson at the ready.

It was quiet.  Too quiet.

The bridge we had set out to capture was undefended, and we quickly set up a defensive position in case a German patrol stumbled upon us.

The sound started as a low rumble.  We looked around, at each other, confused as to why the ground was shaking.  It got louder, and we could soon hear the sound of people yelling.  We readied our weapons, getting ready for the enemy to throw a grenade or fire a Panzerschreck.

But nothing could prepare us for what happened next.

A giant tide of German soldiers, all carrying trench shovels and primed Steilhandgranates in their hands, came around the corner, rushing at us screaming at the top of their lungs.

We opened fire, but there were too many and we were quickly overrun.

Stewart was the first to go, having gotten overzealous with his Thompson.  He had managed to push the wave of Germans back, when they surrounded him and began pummeling him to death with their shovels.

One of them, holding a grenade, charged Rook and Johannson from behind.  They never saw it coming.

By now, it was only me and Peters, him firing his MG wildly at the advancing tide while I threw frag grenade after frag grenade.  And then Peters started to run out of ammo.

Quickly, I rushed up to his position with a new box of ammunition, but by that time they were almost upon him.  Peters quickly pulled out his M1911 and managed to squeeze off a few shots, but it wasn't long before he too was buried under the mass of grey and black.

I was cornered, back against a locked door while I blasted soldier after soldier back with my Sniper rifle.  But it was no use.  They descended upon me, swinging shovels indiscriminately at my already bruised and battered body.  They were relentless, beating me until at last, I succumbed to the darkness.

As my vision blurred, they stopped screaming long enough for one of them to say something to me.

Something that would shock me to the core.

I tried Day of Defeat: Source again recently and was expecting it to be dead. After all, the game is almost a decade old now. However, I was still able to find several populated servers at all hours of the day or night.  Old age hasn‚Äôt killed DOD:S.

If anything age has worked in DOD:S‚Äôs favor. For example, it attracts an older and more mature crowd. I haven‚Äôt had to put up with as much drama or slurs from annoying prepubescent teammates as I do in more modern multiplayer shooters.

Another example of age helping the DOD:S experience is how ‚Äúold school‚Äù it feels. Despite the WW2 setting, DOD:S plays more like an arena shooter from the 1990s than today‚Äôs super serious military shooters. Forget aiming down iron sights. Secondary fire for most weapons throws solid punch instead. Expect to spend a lot of time zipping about, shooting dudes with crosshairs, punching them for good measure, and laughing at the exaggerated ragdoll physics.

Day of Defeat: Source is not a masterpiece but it‚Äôs worth a look if you have a hankering for a shooter that isn‚Äôt too serious.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hbxSkoEqr7g

Before the zeitgeist of perks, leveling and killstreaks consumed the multiplayer shooter market, Valve released an updated version of a successful team based World War 2 Half Life mod on their brand new engine and dubbed it Day of Defeat Source. Released in 2005, Day of Defeat was rooted in another industry fad‚Äîthe world war 2 shooter. In the same year, Medal of Honor European Assault, Call of Duty 2, Brothers in Arms Road to Hill 30 and it's sequel Earned in Blood were all released. While the former games were largely single player story driven affairs, Day of Defeat Source was strictly a team based multiplayer game that distinguished itself by being extraordinarily balanced and offering phenomenal map design.

Players can enlist with either the U.S. Army or the German Wehrmacht and skirmish over capture points or attempt to arm bombs on strategic assets. Each side has six classes that utilize historic weaponry and almost every weapon sets itself apart from the opposite side's equivalent in some way. While the German's Mauser K98 is a single shot bolt action weapon that fires slower than the clip fed semi automatic Garand that the U.S. Army's rifleman class uses, it's also more powerful. Similarly, the Mauser M712 side arm carried by the German Panzerfaust units chews through enemies at close range but the M1 Carbine used by U.S. Rocket troops is far more versatile being semi automatic and highly effective at medium range. With these differences, players often built an allegiance to one army versus another based on their weapon preferences.

Each class also featured a set of quirks that required a bit of practice to master. Machine gunners couldn't effectively kill an enemy unless their gun was mounted, the recoil on these weapons is violent enough to have players staring at the sky box after pulling the trigger. This means that machine gunners are largely a defensive class along with snipers who are hopeless in mid range combat. The assault class utilizes early assault rifles which suffer from heavy recoil and are most effective when fired from a crouched position. Newcomers often favor the support class since their sub machine guns allow the kind of fast moving spray and pray tactics that modern shooter fans are accustomed to but the power and accuracy of rifle troops makes them easy prey at medium to long range where their automatic weapons are almost impotent. While it may be tempting to walk around with a rocket launcher, attempting to aim while moving is incredibly slow making players huge targets. These major differences in the play styles between classes make the experience rewarding and, in some cases, polarizing.

The six official maps offered with the game prove to be masterclasses of map design. In addition to the main lanes that take players to each objective, there are side routes that allow players to flank opponents and remove pesky snipers and machine gunners. Maps that are won by capturing all the territories feature a central capture point that requires at least two teammates to capture meaning it's impossible to go lone wolf and win a game. Uncoordinated teams will often find themselves entrenched in a bitter stalemate over these points‚Äîespecially on Flash which is the most linear map of the bunch. Coordinating your teams efforts and making a big push toward an objective on multiple fronts often yields victory. It's a far cry from the lack of teamwork required by many modern shooter games. While six maps is a bit disappointing the community has stepped in to pad the play-list with hundreds of custom maps.

Valve has continued to support Day of Defeat Source over the years, updating the game to include achievements and trading cards. It's mechanics are almost unrivaled almost a decade after release, in spite of the fact that the popularity of first person shooters has never abated. The aging visuals do little to hamper the thrill of rushing capture points and there are few things more satisfying than putting a bullet in an opponent's head while on the move with a K98. It's a shame that more shooters don't require the skill and cooperation demanded by Day of Defeat Source.

reviewText:
Day of Defeat: Source was, just like Counter-Strike: Source, an update to Valve's new Source engine. I'm not aware at all of how the original Day of Defeat fared, as I never played it, therefore I can't make a proper comparison between the two.

What I can talk about though, is obviously Day of Defeat: Source, having played it quite a bit and having fun with it. The game is set in WW2, and while a lot of games are set in WW2, nowadays with the massive trend of current and near future FPSes lately, it is remarkably a refreshing change.

Source obviously made the maps and models look much better than the original game. They still hold up quite well nowadays, much like Source itself in any case, so for most people there won't be much of a problem when it comes to graphical fidelity.

While I don't know how the gameplay in the original DoD was like, if it was anything like CS 1.6 to CS: Source, it may have ruffled a few feathers on the original DoD community upon DoD: Source's release. Or maybe it didn't, because of the gameplay.

The gameplay is most definitely this game's strong point by a long shot. There are several classes to pick from, varied enough to justify their presence in the game, and fully suit the setting, just like the various weapons you have. The shooting feels good, just like most of the FPSes in Source.

Unfortunately, it suffers from not having a whole lot of variety to it, both in game modes and in maps. And by now, there are naturally also other FPSes set in WW2 that feel and play a lot better than DoD: Source. There's still a community present, so you should have no difficulties jumping into a multiplayer game however.

I would get this game. It's cheap and can be an enjoyable and refreshing game experience once in a while. Plus it's a Valve game, and those come with a lot of obvious perks. (Garry's Mod models being an example) Just don't expect too much out of it.

reviewText:
It's a mad dash as I run to the entrance of the apartment complex. I narrowly dodge MG shots as I sprint through the door, German shouting and loud, continuous gunfire behind me. I eagerly make my way up the stairs as friendly soldiers run down past me. Upon reaching the top floor I greet an allied sniper only to see him get shot in the face. I wait a few good seconds before I peek out one of the windows to see several nazis running towards a capture point. Lifting my M1 Garand to my sights, I carefully follow along and wait for the opportune moment to strike... *crack!* *crack!* *crack!* *PING!* 2 dead, 3 running. I excitedly reload to take the next set of shots, when all of a sudden *BOOM* A panzerschreck round blasts me out of the window to the rubble below...

Welcome to Day of Defeat: Source, a game where you will die often and love every second of it. There are many, many first-person shooters today, so much so that's it's a genre I'm beginning to feel fatigue for. But I can still appreciate when someone does it right. Make no mistake, DoD:S does it right. Guns feel heavy and real, gunshots have force and weight, and gunfights feel fair and rewarding. Every kill is earned here; there are no cheap weapons or exploits. Just you and your mouse. All the maps are paced great and feel distinct. The weapon choice is historically accurate and the guns really do feel like their real-world counterparts. Few shooters reach this level of polish and balance and I feel the need to call that out specifically.

You might get this game and hate it at first cause everyone is accurate and quick and you can't seem to hit anything. But give it a week and start to get skilled and you'll understand the appeal of this bare-bones, good-time, heavy-hitting WWII FPS

reviewText:
If you are a WW2 fan or you love hardcore shooters, this game is for you. Its a way different approach than say, Counter Strike. (You can't compare them and that's not what i'm going to do)

You have 1 gamemode, it involves around capturing flags. There are two teams, the Americans are Germans. Both teams are treated equally (which is awesome, its not like the americans are the good guys and the nazis stupid germans that scream like a girl) and have six classes each with their own sets of weapons. Each class has a ranged attack, melee and explosives (grenades). Most of the classes get a backup pistol with them.
The classes are: (German equipment first, the American and then what they share)
- Rifleman (Mauser Kar89k, M1 Garand and rifle grenades) Has the ability to use ironsights and focuses on long-range combat.
- Assault (MP40 and M1A1 Thompson, a smoke grenade and a frag grenade) For CQB.
- Support (STG-44/MP-44 and B.A.R, 2 frag grenades) For mid and close range and surpressive fire.
- Sniper (Kar98K Scoped and the M1903 Springfield Scoped). No grenades. For long range and to take out classes like other snipers and machinegunners.
- Machinegunner (MG-42 and Browning M1919A4 (I think)) No grenades. Anti sniper, anti machinegunner and to take out large groups of enemies. Must be deployed using the bipod to shoot accurately. (hipfire not advised lol)
- Rocket (not the rocket itself, the class) Uses a Panzershreck and M1 Bazooka. As a secondary you get the Mauser C96 or M1 Carbine (my fav). Anti Sniper and machinegunner.

The classes all have the same health and speed. You die fast (in 1-3 shots, always 1 shot headshot) and rushing is not advised. The game is extremely faced paced and competitive. You need to work together as a team, use your microphone or voice commands to communicate. The voice commands are awesome and well voiced.
Besides that you have the option to go prone (using Z as default I think) This greatly reduced recoil and makes you harder to hit. The disadvantage of it is that when to go prone or out of prone you holster your weapon for 1-2 seconds. I've died many times of this. You get used to it after a while, though. Another option is to sprint. There is a stamina bar that lets you sprint for a few seconds. You cannot shoot while sprinting. In the realism modes, when you get shot in your arm, you drop your primary weapon. A pretty neat feature, but annoying at the same time.

The gunplay itself it pretty well done, it has the same feature as Counter Strike when you are standing still, you accuracy with the most guns is near perfect and when you are moving your accuracy decreases. Almost all the guns have massive recoil, and I mean massive, it takes a lot of skill to master.

The base game comes with a lot of maps and many custom maps too which I don't care about. The stock maps are good and have cool shortcuts and offer a lot of replay value.

There is no singleplayer unless you download a bot mod, which I haven't tried. There are plenty of multiplayer servers to choose from.

The servers mostly consist of 32 player slots, which means 16 vs 16 players.

For active servers DON'T use the serverbrowser, its broken, use Gametracker to locate servers instead. The EdgeGamers servers are pretty good, their clan is EgO (I think). These servers have all the realism settings turned off and have a medic mod that lets you call a medic by typing !medic in the chat. I advise binding this to a key. The medic only heals when your health is below 25 HP (that is when the healthbar turns red). Ping isn't a problem really, but above 150 ping the game becomes unplayable (no ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• sherlock)
There are a lot of realism servers too, but its your choice on what to play.

Community is awesome and mostly mature players. There are daily around 900-1100 players online across all regions.

The game runs almost on every system, I have no problems with it really, and I have a low end PC.

What I hate about Day of Defeat is the constant explosive spam. Grenades deal massive damage and get spammed mostly in doorways and passages. You have the option to throw the grenades back, but this is hard to do. Best to counter the spam is to flank the enemy.

Do I recommend it? Heck yes!

TL:DR: great game I advise you buy it, its worth the full price or wait for steam sale and buy the Valve multiplayer pack. Same price and comes with CSS. (For Gmod textures lol)

reviewText:
This game is pretty cool. Remember when you were only five years old, and you wanted to fight in the army like your pa or grandpa? Well, this game is a bit far back, but you are a soldier fighting in World War 2 in this game! You can choose between being a Nazi or a U.S. soldier in the team selection, and you can pick from six different classes.

You can play as the rifleman, a class armed with the standard rifle of the faction as well as a long range grenade launcher. You can also play as assault, a class that carries a submachine gun as well as a smoke grenade to lay down smoke. You can play as a support, a class sporting a heavy automatic rifle to lay down cover. You can play as a sniper... need an explanation for this? You can play as a machine gunner, armed with a really big gun that can be deployed and mow down a huge group of enemies. Finally, you can be a rocketeer, a class armed with an anti-armor weapon of the faction (rocket launcher) as well as a unique sidearm weapon.

There are two game modes. One is territorial control where you fight over flags you have to capture. The other is a detonation game mode where you have to plant explosives at certain areas of the enemy team.

One problem you may have with this game is the fact that the community is very good because it consists of many people that've played the game for long, so you may find it difficult in that regard. The community is relatively friendly, though. Some servers are very hostile towards profane language, and they ban for some stupid reasons, but there are still good servers out there.

It's just ten dollars. Pop it out and buy it.

reviewText:
My gaming life has revolved around Day of Defeat after my fascination with Half-Life, the mods that came of it, and my family. My brother John (Fuzz) (I use his pseudonym because I look up to my brother and the name is catchy to me) and a few programmers at the time came up with the initial concept of DoD after my brother watched Saving Private Ryan. At an early age (8 or 9) I would watch my brother create sandbox levels within his newly created mod, Day of Defeat. My brother paved the way for Day of Defeat before his departure of the development team (focus on school and relationships) shortly before Valve purchased the mod and turned it into a Valve product.

Soon after my father (Wes) (Fuzzdad) would join in on the efforts to help propel the game forward with level design. My father was a Major in the Army and a helicopter pilot for 13 years, to say he loves history is an understatement. His dedication to the game and meticulous craftsmanship of design with each level was researched, designed, tested, redesigned and re-tested for countless hours. I vividly remember walking downstairs on more than one occasion to his mancave and watching him design what is now known as dod_glider with the Hammer tool, Valve Software's map creation program for their game engine. I am grateful that my father allowed me to playtest his maps and give input. Fuzzdad went on to be a Valve-contracted level designer for dod_glider, dod_flugplatz and dod_falaise. He also created custom maps such as dod_factory and dod_Anvil (Made on Source)

Fuzzdad worked directly with Matt Boone (Main Programmer for DoD/DoD:s and now works on multiple Valve games, also known as Mugsy) with game changes, community map pack releases, updates to stock maps, texture files, sounds, etc. I commend Mugsy for sticking it out as long as he did with DoD/DoD:S by helping the community and working with my father to better the game.

Day of Defeat and Day of Defeat: Source are my favorite multiplayer FPS. It is evident Valve gave up on Day of Defeat: Source after Sourcefilms was tested with DoD:S (The trailers referring to specific maps like Donner) It's hard to blame Valve for lack of content or continuous updates with the game not breaking even on sales. The WW2 era FPS from the 90s and early 2000's has lost the populace favor but that doesn't mean this game is anything less than great.

Do I recommend this game? Yes, yes and yes. DoD:S is a majestic game that has countless replay value and at its core is fun. It's realistic in terms of 1-2 bullet kills. While there is only one true" gamemode (CTF) they also have demolition style maps
date: but the majority of what's left of public servers play CTF or realism. I personally wish they would release a steam workshop for the game or add gamemodes
recommended: but it would be safe to say DoD:S has lost it's prime motivation that it once had years ago. What's left of public servers is mostly realism units which you may or may not like (I personally find them more like a person trying to relive his/her military past and not fun in terms of gameplay) but you as a player might find that style of play different or fun.\n\nTo conclude: Day of Defeat will always be a part of me and my future endeavours in gaming and I hope you the reader give this game a try
hoursPlayed: even if it's not in its prime anymore. It's still enjoyable to pub once in a while.\n\nI'll always have hope for a new DoD

reviewText:
Day of Defeat: Source is my go to World War II shooter, and while it lacks any sort of singleplayer component, what it actually offers is surprisingly good. You play as either an Allied or Axis soldier and work with others on your team to accomplish specific goals, such as capturing objectives or capturing key locations. There are several classes to choose from, so everyone can hopefully find one they excel with.

Visually, the game is (kinda/sorta) beautiful even these days, and the game's vibrant aesthetic style lends itself well to the Source engine that powers it. The models are pretty detailed, yet far from perfect. Moreover, the lighting of the game is actually a factor when picking your shots at other players, because it makes effective use of HDR lighting. So the light and dark colors contrast seamlessly. The weapons are also rendered quite realistically, and sound as such.

Overall, this is a nice game that while being older, still has a decent playerbase and is tremendous fun. I particularly recommend this game!

So much camping they could have made it a WWI game instead.
the high recoil needs quite some time getting used to when playing support,the other guns are controllable.

wanna know more about the classes?here we go:

Rifleman-you are a man,you have a rifle.and two rifle grenades with pretty long range to smoke out mgs and snipers.the M1 garand fires semi-automatic and holds 8 rounds while the k98 is bolt action with 5 rounds.the k98 is a 1 hit kill to the body and head though,the garand needs 2 hits except to the head.
the rifles are also the only weapons with iron-sights.

Assault-armed with a smg,a smoke grenade,a frag grenade and a pistol its great up-close and with controled fire still effective at medium range.they can also use their fists as melee weapons while the smg is equipped.

support-probably the hardest to master,the support class carries two grenades and an automatic rifle thats hard to control but can be effective at all ranges,though its mostly used in close quarters when there are no assault slots free.the stg44 is clearly superior to the BAR,with a larger magazine and less recoil.

sniper-pretty much what you expect,armed with a scoped bolt action rifle and a pistol the ideal class to provide support and pick off machine gunners.but watch your back!

machine gunners-being a true support and defense class,the machine gunner carries a lmg which is pretty much uncontrollable unless set up on its bipod.then it has pretty much no recoil and high accuracy.the german mg42 offers extremely high rates of fire but can overheat,a problem the m1919 browning does not suffer from at the cost of a much lower firerate.they are also armed with the obligatory pistol.

rocketeer-those nutjobs think its a good idea to use rocket launchers against foot soldiers...and it is.the rockets destroy pretty much anyone in their explosion radius,making them ideal to destroy mgs or snipers with indirect fire.besides their rocket launchers they have very powerfull sidearms,the germans a fully automatic modded c96 machine pistol and the americans a m1 carbine which are both much stronger than the regular pistols and even compete with primary weapons.

two more useful tips:

you can pick up armed grenades and throw them back at the enemy,but grenades can be cooked aswell so it depends on the situation when to use it.
besides the assault class all other soldiers have a shovel or knife.when you manage to get behind an enemy a single melee attack will take them out.

good hunting!

reviewText:
I found this game very entertaining and there are still plenty of servers online with a variety of official game modes and maps as well as custom made game modes and maps.

Its hard to say how much time you will get out of this game as it is multiplayer only but if you enjoy it and like the use of WW2 weapon and terrain you should be able to get at least 15-20 hours out of it. That being said i really enjoyed this and clocked 60+ hours.

As for the community of players that are still playing this game; not once did i play a game that had someone screaming or typing abuse to anyone on the server, People actually use their mics for tactical direction on this game rather than telling other players how poor they are etc, that being said, i may have just been lucky with the servers that i played on and the times of day.

You will need to work as a team if you have any hope of playing this game without becoming cannon fodder, If you are the type of player that likes to just run in and gun as soon as round starts then this game is going to frustrate you rather quickly as you rapidly build a negative kill to death ratio. So no grabbing an MG and running and gunning the map up, your team will rely on the covering fire so that they can move up without getting slaughtered, especially seeing as most servers limit the number of a class that can be used by one team, people may get a bit miffed if you have the only mg class and you are actively trying to take flags rather that give covering fire.

I defiantely recommend this game to people if they enjoy online multiplayer and and a ww2 period setting.

reviewText:
Years have passed since the first installment of Day Of Defeat, which was only a mod to Counter Strike 1.6. Day of Defeat:Souce not only has all the fun of the original DoD, but it has become a timeless classic, pretty much like a Rolex or a good bottle of Chateau Lafite Rothschild.

Unlike many newer and more modern FPS, DoD:Source has a loyal fanbase and it is easy to find an online match any time of the day, any day of the week. This is way more than can be said of games like Red Orchestra 2.

Forget about modern graphics: DoD:S is rustic, and takes no toll on even the more modest graphics cards. It runs well on old hardware and even IGPs. There are no visual bells and whistles, and I like it that way. The focus of the game is on playability, and once you're on a match, there is no leveling up, no buying weapons, etc. You pick your class and try your best to kill as many enemies as possible and not to get shot.

I have enjoyed this game for several years, and as long as there are online servers out there, I'll be playing, no matter what new games are released. DoD:S is a classic, immortal FPS.

reviewText:
I found this game very entertaining and there are still plenty of servers online with a variety of official game modes and maps as well as custom made game modes and maps.

Its hard to say how much time you will get out of this game as it is multiplayer only but if you enjoy it and like the use of WW2 weapon and terrain you should be able to get at least 15-20 hours out of it. That being said i really enjoyed this and clocked 60+ hours.

As for the community of players that are still playing this game; not once did i play a game that had someone screaming or typing abuse to anyone on the server, People actually use their mics for tactical direction on this game rather than telling other players how poor they are etc, that being said, i may have just been lucky with the servers that i played on and the times of day.

You will need to work as a team if you have any hope of playing this game without becoming cannon fodder, If you are the type of player that likes to just run in and gun as soon as round starts then this game is going to frustrate you rather quickly as you rapidly build a negative kill to death ratio. So no grabbing an MG and running and gunning the map up, your team will rely on the covering fire so that they can move up without getting slaughtered, especially seeing as most servers limit the number of a class that can be used by one team, people may get a bit miffed if you have the only mg class and you are actively trying to take flags rather that give covering fire.

I defiantely recommend this game to people if they enjoy online multiplayer and and a ww2 period setting.

reviewText: DoD:S is a plenty fun game, and has no major flaws. It's a lot slower-moving and less forgiving than a lot of modern FPS games, and it handles recoil pretty heavily - you can't W+M1 and expect to do well. You have to think about what you're doing and be pretty cautious. The community is kind of small, but weirdly they're the nicest, most courteous playerbase of any online game I've ever played. I feel like this is because most of them are mild-mannered suburban dads who like history. It also feels like most of them are pretty good, like they've been playing since the game came out.\n\nOverall, it's a fun game, and while there's nothing really wrong with it, there's nothing especially great about it either - you probably won't hate the experience, but there's not much to keep you coming back either. Still, you probably won't regret picking it up, even if you just get it so you can use the textures and files for Garry's Mod. Pick it up while it's on sale.

reviewText:
I was playing on the Wehrmacht side against the US alongside with my brother on dod_flash. The americans captured the middle flag and pushed us to the last 2 remaining flags. Shortly after they captured the fourth (farm) flag and we only held our spawn flag. We were on the brink of defeat because everybody in our team were dying over and over but then the two of us stood up and started to push them back. I went around the road through the farm flag and managed to capture it, killing 3 enemies along the way while my brother cleared the houses up to the middle flag. We met up in the middle , shot everyone who where trying to get there and we took it back. Then we finally received reinforcements from our team and we were ready to push the fight to the americans. Our team charged both of their flags and won the round in just over a minute.
Moments like these are awesome in this game and they alone are worth playing the game.

Strategy in DoD:S is more than important and it's so awesome that this FPS game even allows you to do that, ie: well selected classes, good positioned MG's and snipers, smoke grenades - all make a difference in this game. Although alot of strategy may be involved in this game, it's still kinda feels like a classic FPS arcade game with good graphics and source engine which makes it play great. The only shame is that alot of people don't want or try to play as squad or a team to capture or defend flags, in most servers there seems like only 3 - 4 people of total 8-10 ppl in your team try to work together while others are in their own little worlds.

Day of Defeat: Source is a great game, much better than most modern shooters in this day and age and I rate it 9/10

reviewText: Day of Defeat Source is a World War 2 multiplayer shooter by valve and is in the style of counter strike but will you want to play CS or this ? Day of Defeat is essiantly counter strike but set in the world war. You can choose two factions the US or the Germans and you fight it out to win. So how is this game ? This game is actually pretty fun but is no where near as fun as counter strike in my eyes but its still a very good game. Theres not much i can say cause this game is just like counter strike bu there are some diffrences. The maps are way bigger and the guns take some time getting used to. But there are a few negatives i want to talk about. Its quite difficult to find people who play on the official valve servers and not some neon filled maps (even though i kinda like those) but the biggest gripe with this game is the community. If you get on a map thats quite populated you will get kicked off for pretty much anything negative you do. Talking on the mic or playing badly will get you kicked off the server quickly. Overall Day of Defeat Source is  a really good game and without a doubt if you like MP shooters get this game right now. I give Day of Defeat Source an 8/10

reviewText:
Just buy DoD Original, Not source. This game isn't horrid it just isn't the same. If you've never played either it might be a better idea to research the differences between the two. Don't worry that you'll be losing players by going to the older one, both offer just as few populated servers.

I've played a lot of DoD in my day, since the first days of the mod WAY before it was overhauled into what is known as 'original dod' / Day of Defeat on the steam store. Before the overhaul the game was basically a WW2 Team Death Match with 3 points per map. Maps were very crude. Suddenly the mod was overhauled and Valve suddenly became interested after millions of people downloaded it in only a few months, essentially it was the next counter-strike in the day and fell into the hands of valve, back then that wasn't bad.

Even though it say's I have 2 hours of DoD source, I've played since launch. Out of the big source port overs (CS:Source, DoD:Source, TF2) this is definetly the crappier one in contrast to it's original. They simply nerfed it and tried to simplify it, I believe they were trying to stream line it back in the day, but honestly TF2 has more variety then this, and it didn't lose any in contrast to TF:Classic. DoD for HL1 has a lot more diversity for weapon selection, sadly in this version the Axis have very 'unforgiving' weapons that may do slightly more damage, but are horrible to control, while Allies weapons may generally do less damage but are all way more forgiving for recoil; Basically, the original gave both those 'forgiving', 'unforgiving' weapons to both teams except in a couple classes.

They also completely removed the british. The US didn't fight the entire war. Any 3 year old knows that.
